markdown.markdown: ## Objectives - Understand the fundamentals of Repeated Measures ANOVA - Learn the definition and purpose of Repeated Measures ANOVA - Identify the key differences between Repeated Measures ANOVA and One-Way ANOVA - Understand the structure of a Repeated Measures design - Recognize within-subjects factors and levels - Comprehend the sphericity assumption - Understand the Greenhouse-Geisser correction - Calculate Sum of Squares (SS) and Mean Squares (MS) - Conduct hypothesis testing for main effects and interaction - Measure effect sizes and significance - Interpret main effects and interaction - Apply the Bonferroni correction - Check the assumptions of Repeated Measures ANOVA - Explore examples of Repeated Measures ANOVA in nursing research ## Definition and Purpose of Repeated Measures ANOVA Repeated Measures ANOVA is a statistical test used to examine the changes in a continuous dependent variable across multiple measurements over time or under different conditions. It is an extension of [One-Way ANOVA](introduction-to-anova.qmd) but accounts for the correlation between repeated measures on the same subjects. ### Key Differences Between Repeated Measures ANOVA and One-Way ANOVA - **One-Way ANOVA:** Evaluates the effect of a single independent variable on a continuous outcome. - **Repeated Measures ANOVA:** Evaluates the effect of a single or multiple within-subject factors over time, accounting for the correlation between repeated measurements. ## Understanding the Structure of a Repeated Measures Design In a Repeated Measures design, each participant is measured multiple times under different conditions or over time. The design includes: - **Within-Subjects Factors:** Variables measured repeatedly on the same subjects. - **Levels:** The different conditions or time points for each within-subjects factor. ### Example Structure - **Within-Subjects Factor:** Time - **Levels:** Baseline, Week 1, Week 2, Week 3 ## Sphericity Assumption Sphericity refers to the assumption that the variances of the differences between all combinations of related groups are equal. If violated, it can lead to biased F-statistics and increased Type I errors. ### Greenhouse-Geisser Correction The Greenhouse-Geisser correction adjusts the degrees of freedom to correct for violations of sphericity, providing a more conservative estimate. ## Calculation of SS (Sum of Squares) and MS (Mean Squares) ### Sum of Squares - **Total Sum of Squares (SST):** $$ SST = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{t} (Y_{ij} - \bar{Y})^2 $$ where ( Y\_{ij} ) is each individual observation, and ( \bar{Y} ) is the overall mean. - **Sum of Squares Within (SSW):** $$ SSW = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{t} (Y_{ij} - \bar{Y}_{i\cdot})^2 $$ where ( \bar{Y}\_{i\cdot} ) is the mean of all measurements for subject ( i ). - **Sum of Squares Between (SSB):** $$ SSB = \sum_{j=1}^{t} n_j (\bar{Y}_{\cdot j} - \bar{Y})^2 $$ where ( \bar{Y}\_{\cdot j} ) is the mean for level ( j ), and ( n_j ) is the number of observations at level ( j ). ### Mean Squares - **Mean Square Within (MSW):** $$ MSW = \frac{SSW}{(n - 1)(t - 1)} $$ - **Mean Square Between (MSB):** $$ MSB = \frac{SSB}{t - 1} $$ ## Hypothesis Testing for Main Effects and Interaction ### Hypotheses - **Main Effect of Within-Subjects Factor:** - Null Hypothesis (( H_0 )): No difference in the means across levels. - Alternative Hypothesis (( H_1 )): At least one level has a different mean. - **Interaction Effect:** - Null Hypothesis (( H_0 )): No interaction between within-subjects factors. - Alternative Hypothesis (( H_1 )): An interaction exists between factors. ### F-Ratio Calculations - **Main Effect of Within-Subjects Factor:** $$ F = \frac{MSB}{MSW} $$ ### Interpretation - Compare the F-ratio to the critical value from the F-distribution. - If the calculated F-ratio is greater than the critical value, reject the null hypothesis. ## Effect Sizes and Significance ### Eta Squared (( \eta\^2 )) Represents the proportion of the total variance explained by the within-subjects factor. - **Within-Subjects Factor:** $$ \eta^2 = \frac{SSB}{SST} $$ ## Bonferroni Correction A post-hoc correction used to reduce Type I errors when multiple comparisons are made. When conducting multiple tests, the risk of a false positive (Type I error) increases significantly. For a detailed explanation of why this happens, see the section on [The Problem of Multiple Comparisons](introduction-to-anova.qmd#the-problem-of-multiple-comparisons) in the ANOVA lecture. ### Formula $$ \alpha_{\text{corrected}} = \frac{\alpha}{m} $$ where ( m ) is the number of comparisons. ## Checking Assumptions of Repeated Measures ANOVA ### Sphericity - Use Mauchly's test to check the assumption of sphericity. ### Normality - Use Q-Q plots to check the normality of residuals. ### Homogeneity of Variances - Ensure variances are approximately equal across conditions. ## Examples of Repeated Measures ANOVA in Nursing Research ### Example 1: Evaluating Blood Pressure Changes Over Time - **Research Question:** How does blood pressure change over a 3-week intervention period? - **Within-Subjects Factor:** Time - **Levels:** Baseline, Week 1, Week 3 - **Response Variable:** Blood Pressure download example data (CSV) ```{r, eval=FALSE} # Example in R # Simulated data set.seed(123) data <- data.frame( Subject = rep(1:20, each = 3), Time = factor(rep(c("Baseline", "Week1", "Week3"), times = 20)), BP = rnorm(60, mean = rep(c(120, 115, 110), each = 20), sd = 10) ) # Repeated Measures ANOVA install.packages("ez") library(ez) anova_results <- ezANOVA( data = data, dv = BP, wid = Subject, within = Time ) print(anova_results) ``` ### Example 2: Evaluating Cognitive Function Changes Over Multiple Sessions - **Research Question:** How does cognitive function change across four training sessions? - **Within-Subjects Factor:** Session - **Levels:** Session 1, Session 2, Session 3, Session 4 - **Response Variable:** Cognitive Function Score download example 2 data (CSV) ```{r, eval=FALSE} # Example in R # Simulated data set.seed(456) data2 <- data.frame( Subject = rep(1:15, each = 4), Session = factor(rep(c("Session1", "Session2", "Session3", "Session4"), times = 15)), Score = rnorm(60, mean = rep(c(80, 85, 90, 95), each = 15), sd = 5) ) # Repeated Measures ANOVA library(ez) anova_results2 <- ezANOVA( data = data2, dv = Score, wid = Subject, within = Session ) print(anova_results2) ```

**Main Effect of Within-Subjects Factor:** - Null Hypothesis (( H_0 )): No difference in the means across levels. - Alternative Hypothesis (( H_1 )): At least one level has a different mean. - **Interaction Effect:** - Null Hypothesis (( H_0 )): No interaction between within-subjects factors. - Alternative Hypothesis (( H_1 )): An interaction exists between factors. ### F-Ratio Calculations - **Main Effect of Within-Subjects Factor:** $$ F = \frac{MSB}{MSW} $$ ### Interpretation - Compare the F-ratio to the critical value from the F-distribution. - If the calculated F-ratio is greater than the critical value, reject the null hypothesis. ## Effect Sizes and Significance ### Eta Squared (( \eta\^2 )) Represents the proportion of the total variance explained by the within-subjects factor. - **Within-Subjects Factor:** $$ \eta^2 = \frac{SSB}{SST} $$ ## Bonferroni Correction A post-hoc correction used to reduce Type I errors when multiple comparisons are made. When conducting multiple tests, the risk of a false positive (Type I error) increases significantly. - **Within-Subjects Factor:** Time - **Levels:** Baseline, Week 1, Week 3 - **Response Variable:** Blood Pressure download example data (CSV) ```{r, eval=FALSE} # Example in R # Simulated data set.seed(123) data <- data.frame( Subject = rep(1:20, each = 3), Time = factor(rep(c("Baseline", "Week1", "Week3"), times = 20)), BP = rnorm(60, mean = rep(c(120, 115, 110), each = 20), sd = 10) ) # Repeated Measures ANOVA install.packages("ez") library(ez) anova_results <- ezANOVA( data = data, dv = BP, wid = Subject, within = Time ) print(anova_results) ``` ### Example 2: Evaluating Cognitive Function Changes Over Multiple Sessions - **Research Question:** How does cognitive function change across four training sessions? - **Within-Subjects Factor:** Session - **Levels:** Session 1, Session 2, Session 3, Session 4 - **Response Variable:** Cognitive Function Score download example 2 data (CSV) ```{r, eval=FALSE} # Example in R # Simulated data set.seed(456) data2 <- data.frame( Subject = rep(1:15, each = 4), Session = factor(rep(c("Session1", "Session2", "Session3", "Session4"), times = 15)), Score = rnorm(60, mean = rep(c(80, 85, 90, 95), each = 15), sd = 5) ) # Repeated Measures ANOVA library(ez) anova_results2 <- ezANOVA( data = data2, dv = Score, wid = Subject, within = Session ) print(anova_results2) ```
